You can return to fertility and have more children once you stop any method.nbsp The methods for quick return to fertility are: The most effective methods are the Implants and IUD Other effective methods are the pills and diaphragm and the least effective methods you can use are the condoms, abstinence from sex on fertile days, and the withdrawal method.

The effects of contraceptive methods on sex life can vary depending on individual experiences and preferences. Some methods, like hormonal contraceptives (such as birth control pills, patches, or IUDs), may have side effects like changes in libido, mood swings, or dryness. However, these effects are not universal, and many individuals use contraceptives without experiencing negative impacts on their sex lives. Other non-hormonal methods like condoms or copper IUDs typically don't affect libido. Ultimately, it's essential to discuss any concerns or potential side effects with a healthcare provider to find the best option that suits your needs and lifestyle.nbsp

nbspNinu gbogbo àwọn ìlànà ti o rọrun lati lo, ìlànà ti o munadoko julọ ni awọn ifetosomobibi alapa. nbspÀwọn ìlànà ti o tún rọrun miiran lati gba ni Àwọn Alabẹrẹ ati Awọn Oògùn. nbspÌlànà ti o kere julọ (ṣugbọn sibẹ 99) ti o le lo ni Àwọn Kondomu.

nbspÀwọn ìlànà ti ko ni irora patapata ni àwọn kondomu àti awọn daafuramu ṣugbọn wọn ko munadoko bi àwọn alabẹrẹ, àwọn onigbigbin sára àti àwọn iṣeto ifibọ ile ọmọ. Pẹlu àwọn alabẹrẹ àti àwọn onigbigbin sára, ọpọlọpọ àwọn ènìyàn ko ni iriri àwọn ìpalára ṣugbọn àwọn ènìyàn diẹ ni iriri àwọn ẹfọri kekere.nbsp Pẹlu àwọn Iṣeto Ifibọ ile ọmọ ọpọlọpọ ènìyàn ko ni iriri ìnira kankan lẹhin ifibọ ṣugbọn àwọn ènìyàn diẹ ni irora ikun kekere.

nbsp Àwọn ìpalára ti awọn ìlànà adèna oyún lori igbe ayé ibalopọ le yatọ si ará wọn, o da lori awọn iriri ati àwọn irufẹ ẹni kọọkan. nbspDiẹ ninu àwọn ilana, bii àwọn idena oyún homonu (bii àwọn oogun iṣakoso ibimọ, abulẹ, tàbí awọn IUDs), le ni àwọn ìpalára bi awọn ayipada nilibido, àwọn iyipada iṣesi, tàbí gbigbẹ. nbspSibẹsibẹ, àwọn ìpalára wọnyi kii ṣe ohun tó wọpọ, àti pé ọpọlọpọ ènìyàn n lo àwọn ìdènà oyún lai ni iriri àwọn ìpalára lori igbe aye ibalopọ wọn. nbspÀwọn ìlànà miiran ti kii ṣe ti homonu bi kondomu tàbí àwọn Iṣeto Ifibọ ile ọmọ ko ni ìpalára si libido rara. nbspNi igbẹhin, o ṣe pataki lati jíròrò eyikeyi àwọn ìdààmú tàbí àwọn ìpalára ti o pọju pẹlu olupese ìlera lati wa ìlànà ti o dara julọ ti o se ibamu pẹlú àwọn ohun ti o fẹ àti sì igbesi aye rẹ.

Lubricants, also called gels or lubes, are special fluids used during sex. They help reduce friction, discomfort, and dryness, making sex more pleasurable and preventing condoms from breaking. Lubricants come in water-based, silicone-based, or oil-based types. Water-based lubes are safe with all condoms, they don't change the vagina's pH, don't stain clothes, and wash off easily with water. Silicone and oil-based lubes should only be used with specific condom materials. Click to listen to a short introduction of Lubricant in Pidgin, if you want.

nbspPenegra is a product that used to treat erectile dysfunction. Erectile Dysfunction refers to the consistent/inability of a man to obtain an erection sufficient for satisfactory sex. Penegra helps to induce a hard erection which can last for an extended duration thereby enhancing confidence, well-being, and satisfaction. Penegra only induces a hard erection when the penis is stimulated.

IUDs are very effective in preventing pregnancy (gt99). If you would like to discuss itnbsp in more details with a medical professional, please call 7790.nbsp

The IUD does not have any negative effects on your health.nbsp If you're still worried about the IUD and its effects on your health, it's important to talk to a healthcare provider. They can provide personalized advice and address any concerns you may have.
We understand some methods could get too costly. Please call 7790nbspand a medical professional will help you to find a more affordable solution.
The IUD is very convenient to use. If you are experiencing any form of discomfort, kindly call 7790 for free to speak to a nurse.

Complications are rare but may occur and they include: 1. Expulsion of IUD, which may lead to pregnancy. 2. Uterine perforation. They might cause some side effects such as: a. Irregular and heavy period or bleeding. b. Menstrual cramps. c. Abnormal vaginal discharge. Normally, theynbspwear out after a few weeks.nbspIf your symptoms are not mentioned above or you are still worried, please visit your family planning provider.
Complications like that are rare, but possible. Please call 7790 so medical professional will help to find a better solution.
There is nothing to be ashamed when doing family planning. Moreover, with the IUD, no one will know you are using it.
The IUD method is safe and you can have more children when you stop using it. It is possible almost immediately.

The effects of contraceptive methods on sex life can vary depending on individual experiences and preferences. Some methods, like hormonal contraceptives (such as birth control pills, patches, or IUDs), may have side effects like changes in libido, mood swings, or dryness. However, these effects are not universal, and many individuals use contraceptives without experiencing negative impacts on their sex lives. Other non-hormonal methods like condoms or copper IUDs typically don't affect libido. Ultimately, it's essential to discuss any concerns or potential side effects with a healthcare provider to find the best option that suits your needs and lifestyle.nbsp

Lubricants, also called gels or lubes, are special fluids used during sex. They help reduce friction, discomfort, and dryness, making sex more pleasurable and preventing condoms from breaking. Lubricants come in water-based, silicone-based, or oil-based types. Water-based lubes are safe with all condoms, they don't change the vagina's pH, don't stain clothes, and wash off easily with water. Silicone and oil-based lubes should only be used with specific condom materials. Click to listen to a short introduction of Lubricant in Pidgin, if you want.

Penegra only induces a hard erection when the penis is stimulated.

If you are ovulating, you should use an alternative contraceptive plan (condoms). Please note that they are not effective if you are already pregnant.

Postpill is a one-dose emergency contraceptive pill by DKT. It contains 1.5 mg Levongestrel. POSTPILL should be taken orally as soon as possible within 24 hours but can still be taken within 5 days (120 hours) of unprotected sex. You can buy Postpill at any pharmacy or health store around you.

Postinor is an Emergency Contraceptive Pill (ECP) that safely prevents unwanted pregnancy within 72 hours after unprotected sexual intercourse. It doesnt work if you are already pregnant and will not harm an already established pregnancy. The sooner you take POSTINOR, the more effective it is. You can buy Postinor at any pharmacy or health store around you.

Daily pills are combined oral contraceptive (COC) pills for pregnancy prevention, dermatological and gynecological conditions, and management of menstrual irregularities (heavy bleeding, painful menstruation, premenstrual syndrome). They work by thickening the mucus around the cervix, which makes it difficult for sperm to enter the uterus and reach any eggs that may have been released. Daily pills are either a 21-day pack (Dianofem and Desofem) or a 28-day pack (Levofem). One pill is taken each day at about the same time for 21 days. Depending on your pack, you will either have a 7-day break (as in the 21-day pack) or you will take the pill that contains Iron for 7 days (the 28-day pack).
Click to listen to a short introduction of daily pills in Pidgin, if you want to.

Some of the advantages and disadvantages of daily pills includes. Advantages 1. They are very effective if used correctly. 2. Very safe for the majority of women. 3. Return to fertility is very fast. 4. They regularize the menstrual cycle, reduce heavy menstrual flow, and reduce menstrual and ovulation pain. 5. They are simple and easy to use.

and Disadvantages 1. They must be taken daily which might be difficult to comply with. 2. They might cause mild and temporary side effect which usually goes away after some weeks such as: a. Mild headache. b. Nausea or vomiting. c. Spotting or bleeding at intervals. d. Breast tenderness and soreness to touch. e. Mood changes.

Now let me tell you who can use and who cannot use daily pills. Who can use 1.You can use daily pills if you want a short-term contraceptive method. 2. If you are a breastfeeding mother (from six months after birth) 3. If you have irregular menstrual cycle. 4. If you don't have migrainous headaches. 5. If you are taking antibiotics, antifungal or antiparasitic medications.

Levofem is a safe, low-dose, combined oral contraceptive used to prevent pregnancy. Each pack contains 21 active yellow tablets and 7 placebo(inactive) tablets which should be taken around the same time daily.
You can buy Levofem at any pharmacy or health store around you.

How to Use 1. Take your first pill from the packet marked with the correct day of the week, or the first pill of the first colour (phasic pills) 2. Continue to take a pill at the same time each day until the pack is finished. Continue taking pills for seven days (during these seven days you will get a bleed). 3. Start your next pack of pills on the eighth day, whether you are still bleeding or not. This should be the same day of the week as when you took your first pill

Dianofem is a safe and effective pill that contains a combination of an antiandrogen (Cyprolerone Acetate 2mg) and estrogen (Ethinylestradiol 0.035mg) used for the treatment of dermatological and gynecological conditions in women. It also prevents pregnancy. It contains 21 tablets with no placebo (inactive pills).
How to Use Take one tablet daily for 21 days, followed by a 7-day break where no tablets are taken. Start the next pack after the 7-day break.
How to Use One pill is taken around the same time daily for 21 days followed by a 7-day break, then continue with the next pack.

Injectable contraceptives are a form of hormonal birth control for women. They consist of 2-3 monthly injections containing an estrogen and a progestin to prevent pregnancy. The injectionnbspworks by preventing the ovaries from releasing an egg each month. It also thickens the fluid around the cervix. They can be used for pregnancy prevention for 1 to 3 months.

A diaphragm or cap is a type of barrier contraceptive device inserted into the vagina before sex to cover the cervix so that sperm can't get into the womb (uterus). You need to use spermicide with it (spermicides kill sperm). The diaphragm must be left in place for at least 6 hours after sex. The diaphragm is a vaginal barrier contraceptive that is woman-controlled, nonhormonal, and appropriate for women who cannot or do not want to use hormonal contraceptive methods, intrauterine devices, or condoms.
Click to listen to a short introduction of diaphragm in Pidgin, if you want.

Some of the advantages and disadvantages of Diaphragms. Advantages 1. Diaphragms do not have hormones, so no side effects. 2. Good option for women who prefer non-hormonal contraceptive methods. 3. They may be fitted at any time (post-partum mothers must wait for 6 weeks after delivery or mid-trimester abortion)nbsp 4. They can be inserted up to 6 hours before sex to avoid interruption.nbsp 5. Only used when needed and gives the woman absolute control. 6. One size fits most women. 7. Portable and convenient - it comes with a specially designed case that is discreet and fits in a bag. 8. Easy to use - insertion and removal gets better with practice. 9. Can be used for up to 2 years with proper care.

andnbsp Disadvantages 1. They are not readily available in Nigeria. 2. They may be expensive to some users. 3. The user must remember to insert the diaphragm before intercourse and keep it in place for at least 6 hours after sex (but not more than 24 hours)nbsp 4. They require special care and storage. 5. They can cause urinary tract infections. 6. A different size of diaphragm may be required after childbirth or if a woman gains weight. 7. They can be damaged by excessive use or poor storagenbsp

Contraceptive implants are small, flexible rods inserted under the skin, typically in the arm. They release hormones (usually progestin) to prevent pregnancy. They are long-term birth control methods also called long-acting reversible contraception, or LARC. They provide contraception, lasting up to 3 - 5 years but can be removed at any time. They work by preventing the release of egg and thickening the cervical mucus making it difficult for sperm to reach the egg.
Click to listen to a short explanation of implants in Pidgin, if you want to.

Some of the advantages and disadvantages of contraceptive implants. Advantages 1. They can be used at any time in the menstrual cycle, are very effective, and are removed whenever you want to get pregnant. 2. It gives total privacy, no one will know you have it and does not interfere with sex. 3. No frequent clinical follow-up is needed after initial insertion. 4. It is estrogen-free so many people can use it 5. They are long-acting and may help prevent ectopic pregnancy. 6. Does not disturb breast milk production. 7. There is no delay in return to fertility when they are removed.

Now let me tell you who can use and who cannot use implants. Who can use 1. You can use an implant if you want to prevent pregnancy for up to 1 to 3 years. 2. If you are a breastfeeding mother (from 6 weeks after birth) 3. If you cannot tolerate estrogen. 4. If you don't have migrainous headaches. 5. If you have endometrial or ovarian cancer, you can still use this method.

Disadvantages 1. Insertion and removal involve minor surgery and must be performed by a trained professional. 2. You cannot discontinue the method by yourself. 3. They might have some side effects such as: a. Headache. b. Nausea or vomiting. c. Dizziness. d. Breast tenderness. e. Weight gain. f. Menstrual changes. g. Spotting and irregular vaginal bleeding.

Who cannot use You cannot use implants if you have any of the following medical conditions. a. Uncontrolled hypertension. b. Venous thromboembolism. c. Stroke. d. Heart Disease. e. Liver Disease. f. Breast Cancer. g. Kidney infection. h. Vaginal bleeding.

LEVOPLANT which is a subdermal contraceptive implant, Levoplant has two small flexible rods about matchstick size. It is WHO-prequalified and highly effective for 3 years, it is suitable for most women except pregnant women.

Advantages  Immediate return to fertility.  Fewer side effects.  Thinner trocar for the insertion process.nbsp  High quality and most affordable 3-year implant in Nigeria. Jadelle is a contraceptive implant that consists of two small flexible rods (as short as a match stick but thinner) that is inserted under the skin of a womans upper arm. It contains 75mg of the hormone Levonorgestrel in each rod. Jadelle implants are over 99 effective and can prevent pregnancy for a period of 5 years. This method is completely and quickly reversible because it releases very low dose of hormone which leaves the body quickly when removed, so the woman can get pregnant without delay.
You can visit a family planning clinic/provider if you want to adopt this method.

Implanon NXT is a contraceptive implant that consists of one small flexible rod that is inserted under the skin of a womans upper arm. It contains 65mg of the hormone Etonorgestrel in each rod. Implanon NXT is over 99 effective and can prevent pregnancy for 3 years. Also, it can be stopped anytime the woman wants by asking a health provider to remove it. This method is completely and quickly reversible because it releases a very low dose of hormone, which leaves the body quickly when removed, so you woman can get pregnant without delay.
Some of its common side effects are  Headaches.  Dizziness.  Breast tenderness.  Nausea  Stomach cramping/bloating.  Weight gain.  Vaginal irritation/discharge may occur.
If you want to prevent pregnancy for up to 3 - 4 years, it is advisable to adopt long-acting reversible contraception or LARC methods.

Long-acting reversible contraception, or LARC are: 1. The Injectables. 2. The Implants. 3. The IUS. 4. The IUD While the short-acting methods are: 1. The daily contraceptive Pills. 2. The emergency contraceptive pills. 3. The barrier contraceptives Choose any them from the options to get the full details about them.
You can still adopt the short-acting family planning methods or the barrier contraceptives if you don't want any device insertion into your body.

Intrauterine system (IUS) are hormonal intrauterine device (IUD). They contain Levenorgestrel for the treatment of some gynecological conditions (endometriosis, adenomyosis, endometrial hyperplasia, etc.) and pregnancy prevention. It has contraceptive coverage for up to 5 years.

How they worknbsp For pregnancy prevention, it works by thickening the mucus in the cervix to stop sperm from fertilizing an egg. It also thins out the lining of the uterus and suppresses ovulation and for gynaecological conditions, it reduces the endometrial lining of the womb making the period lighter and less painful.

Some of the advantages and disadvantages of IUS. Advantages For pregnancy prevention: 1. No daily use is required. 2. Insertion and removal can be done at any time within the menstrual cycle. 3. Do not require regular clinic visits. 4. It has a quick return to fertility after removal. 5. Safe for breastfeeding mothers from six weeks after delivery. 6. Local release of the home ensures milder side effects. 7. It maintains normal libido. 8. Reduces the risk of ovarian cancer and endometrial cancer. 9. Lower overall risk of ectopic pregnancy than women not on contraception. For gynecological use: 1. Starts working within 24 hours after insertion. 2. Highly effective for the treatment of abnormally heavy menstrual bleeding. 3. Lowers the risk of anemia due to menstrual blood loss. 4. Effective alternative to surgery especially for women who cannot afford to pay for surgery.
Click to listen to a short explanation of IUS in Pidgin, if you want to.
This means that you can use IUS for both gynecological matters and to prevent pregnancy.

Now to the disadvantages of IUS. Disadvantages 1. Your periods may become irregular or stop completely, which may not be suitable for some people. 2. Self-limiting follicular cysts may develop in the first few cycles. 3. If you get an infection when you have an IUS fitted, it could lead to a pelvic infection if it's not treated. 4. In rare cases, an IUS can make a hole in the womb when it's put in. 5. They might have some side effects such as: a. Headache. b. Nausea or vomiting. c. Breast tenderness. d. Lower abdominal cramps. e. Irregular uterine/vaginal bleeding.
Now let me tell you who can use and who cannot use IUS. Who can use 1. You can use IUS if you cannot use combined contraceptives. 2. If can use IUS even if you are HIV positive.

Who cannot use You cannot use IUS if you have any of the following medical conditions. a. Uncontrolled hypertension. b. Stroke. c. Heart Disease. d. Liver Disease. e. Breast Cancer. f. Cervical cancer. g. Kidney infection. h. Unexplained vaginal bleeding

Eloira, which is an IUS different from an IUD due to the absence of copper. A hormone (Levonorgestrel) replaces the copper. It is used to treat gynecological conditions and pregnancy prevention.

An IUD (Intrauterine Device) is a small T or Y-shaped contraceptive device inserted into the uterus to prevent pregnancy for up to 10 years. They are usually called Copper T or Copper Y. Theynbspare long-lasting, easily reversible, safe, and more than 99 effective in preventing unintendednbsppregnancy. They work by providing an environment that is toxic and hostile for the sperm thereby preventing them from fertilizing an egg.
Click to listen to a short explanation of IUD in Pidgin, if you want to.

Some of the advantages and disadvantages of IUD. Advantages 1. IUDs are highly effective and safe for a majority of women. 2. They are 100 hormone-free, so no hormonal side effects. 3. Can be removed at any time with immediate return to fertility. 4. Can be used as an emergency contraceptive if inserted within 5 days of having unprotected sex. 5. They are private and independent of intercourse. 6. They are long-lasting and can prevent pregnancy for up to 10 years with no drug interaction.

Now to the disadvantages of IUD. Disadvantages Complications are rare but may occur and they include 1. Expulsion of IUD, which may lead to pregnancy. 2. Uterine perforation. 3. They might cause some side effects such as: a. Irregular and heavy period or bleeding. b. Menstrual cramps. c. Abnormal vaginal discharge.

Now let me tell you who can use and who cannot use IUD. Who can use 1. You can use an IUD if you are very sexually active. 2. You can use an IUD even if you are a breastfeeding mother, a smoker, or have diabetes and hypertension. 3. You can use an IUD if you have currently or history of certain health conditions like stroke, heart disease, liver disease, breast cancer, headaches, lupus, vein thrombosis, etc, and cannot use hormonal contraceptives. 4. You can use an IUD even if you are taking drugs like anti-tuberculosis drugs, anti-convulsant drugs, or anti-retroviral agents, etc.

Who cannot use You cannot use an IUD if you have any of the following medical conditions. a. Cervical cancer. b. Endometrial disease. c. Unexplained vaginal bleeding. d. Uterine fibroid with cavity distortion. e. Pelvic tuberculosis. f. Untreated vaginal infection. g. STIs like gonorrhoea and chlamydia.
So do you currently have or previously had any of the medical conditions listed?
OK, sorry about your medical condition but it is not advisable for you to use IUD. Please speak to your doctor before using this method of contraception.
Do you understand? It is very important.
Ok, let me show you one of the effective IUD products that you can adopt.

Lydia IUD devices are non-hormonal, long-lasting contraception (5-10 yrs.) DKT has 5 variants which can be T (the most common) or Y-shaped - made of plastic coat with copper. This device is inserted into the uterus and it is the most effective contraceptive according to WHO with about 99.9 efficacy. It can also serve as an emergency contraceptive if used within 5days of unprotected sexual intercourse. Its mechanism of action is to inhibit sperm penetration due to the toxicity of copper to sperm

Permanent family planning methods means the person will no longer be able to reproduce again.nbsp Male: Vasectomy Female: Tubal ligation Click on any of them to get a short explanation on them.

Vasectomy is a form of male birth control that cuts the supply of sperm to your semen. It's done by cutting and sealing the tubes that carry sperm. Vasectomy has a low risk of problems and can usually be performed in an outpatient setting under local anesthesia. You will need to consult a health care provider.

Tubal Litigation is surgery women can get to "tie" their fallopian tubes. It's a type ofnbspfemale sterilization. The goal is to prevent eggs from travelling from the ovaries to the uterus so you can'tnbspget pregnant.
Some of its common side effects are: a. Abdominal pain or cramping. b. Fatigue. c. Dizziness. d. Gassiness or bloating. e. Shoulder pain. You will need to consult a health care provider.

The effects of contraceptive methods on sex life can vary depending on individual experiences and preferences. Some methods, like hormonal contraceptives (such as birth control pills, patches, or IUDs), may have side effects like changes in libido, mood swings, or dryness. However, these effects are not universal, and many individuals use contraceptives without experiencing negative impacts on their sex lives. Other non-hormonal methods like condoms or copper IUDs typically don't affect libido. Ultimately, it's essential to discuss any concerns or potential side effects with a healthcare provider to find the best option that suits your needs and lifestyle.nbsp
